#### 1 True False

![](/Photos/NPE3%20Q1.png)

Suppose we're interested to know that a population parameter $K$ equals some value $K_0$. We calculate a test statistic $S$ from the sample estimate $K$ to base our inference on. The larger $K$ is compared to $K_0$, the larger the value of $S$ becomes.

The figure above shows the density distribution on which the test is based on. This distribution is one of those covered in the course, so the normal, T, chi squared or *F distribution*. The test value $S$ in shown in red, and the critical value(s) used for the inference in blue.

![https://blog.minitab.com/en/blog/statistics-in-the-field/a-field-guide-to-statistical-distributions](/Photos/Distribution_Guide.png)

**Indicate for every statement below whether it is consistent with the figure above (TRUE) or not (FALSE)**

We do not have enough evidence to state that $K$ is equal to $K_0$

| TRUE: The test value is less than the critical value on a left tailed test. We reject the null hypothesis.

The test assumes that $K$ follows a $F$ distribution

| Not Sure: The graph looks like an F distribution, but it could also be a chi-squared distribution. The photo name is F

~~In this test the significance level~~ $\alpha$ ~~is set to 0.95~~

| FALSE : The area under the curve to the right of the critical value is 0.95. This indicates that alpha is set to 0.05.

The alternative hypothesis is $K < K_0$

| TRUE: The graph shows that 95% of the estimated population is greater than the critical value. For a significant result supporting that $K<K_0$ we look for a test value below the critical value. TRUE

We do not have enough evidence to state that $K$ is smaller than $K_0$

| FALSE: At the 0.05 significance level, we have enough evidence to say that $K$ is smaller than $K_0$

#### 2 Comparing More Than Two Populations

| PC Lab 4 pg.6

Fusarium wilt is an important fungal disease that wrecks havoc in banana plantations. Researchers are hunting for more resistant cultivars, and identified three possible candidates. They went to an area where wilt is a problem, and counted for each cultivar how many fields were infected and how many were not. The results are shown in the table below:

|              | Cultivar 1 | Cultivar 2 | Cultivar 3 |
|--------------|------------|------------|------------|
| Infected     | 14         | 28         | 10         |
| Not Infected | 23         | 10         | 8          |

The researchers want to know whether any of these cultivars differs in susceptibility to the disease from the other ones. Use an appropriate test to evaluate their claim and report the requested values.

$H_0: \pi_1 = \pi_2 = \pi_3$

$H_A$ : At least two proportions differ

Report the value of the test statistic you used, rounded to 3 decimals.

```{r}
x <- c(14,28,10)
n <- c(37,38,18)

test <- prop.test(x,n)
test
round(test[["statistic"]], 3)
```

Report the degrees of freedom for the distribution used as the probability model.

```{r}
test["parameter"]
```

Report the corresponding p-value rounded to 4 significant digits (0.0001457 is correct, 0.0001 is not!)

```{r}
signif(test[['p.value']], digits = 4)
```

Select the correct conclusion based on the test you reported. \> At the 1% significance level, we find proof for a significant difference in the proportion of affected fields between cultivars. The proportion of affected fields is estimated to be 38%, 74% and 56% for the different cultivars.

#### 3 Tests for Data from a Normal Distribution

| Lecture Notes Pg. 86
| Hypothesis Testing Slide 25

To avoid overfertilization, farmers should only add extra potassium to their fields when the STK (soil test potassium) value of the soil is lower than a certain value. This value is determined to be 170 ppm for clay soils and *135 ppm for sandy soils*. A farmer has fields with *sandy soil*, and wants to know whether she needs to add extra potassium to her field. She measured the STK value at *11* different spots and found an average potassium value of *128.8* ppm with a standard deviation of *22.3* ppm.

$$ Potassium \sim N(128.8, 22.3); n=11$$

Use the most appropriate test to evaluate whether she has to add potassium to her field or not, assuming the STK values within a field are normally distributed.

$H_0: \mu_{sample} = 135$

$H_0: \mu_{sample} < 135$

Report the value of the test statistic rounded to 3 decimals. Pay attention to the sign!

![](/Photos/T%20Statistic%20Formula.png)

```{r}
x_bar <- 128.8
s <- 22.3
n <- 11
mu_0 <- 135
alpha = 0.1 # conclusion section of question

t <- x_bar-mu_0/(s/sqrt(n))

qt(alpha, 
   df = n-1, 
   lower.tail = TRUE)
```

Report the degrees of freedom for the distribution of the statistic.

```{r}
n-1
```

Report the corresponding p-value rounded to 4 significant digits (0.0001457 is correct, 0.0001 is not!)

```{r}

```

Select the most appropriate conclusion.

#### 6 Paired or Unpaired

Seaweed extract is said to improve the speed of photosynthesis in tomato plants. To determine whether this is true, researchers set up a series of experiments where they measure CO2 uptake using a standard CI-340 photosynthesis measurement tool.

![Lecture Notes pg.112](Photos/Paired%20and%20Unpaired.png)

Researchers divide 40 plants in two groups. Every plant is treated with two seaweed extracts, A and B. The first group gets extract A first, and two weeks later extract B. The second group gets B first and then A. For each seaweed formula, the difference in CO2 uptake before and one week after application of the treatment is measured. The differences are calculated and compared between both extracts.

`My gut is telling me unpaired but each plant has multiple measurements.`

The baseline CO2 uptake is measured for 40 plants. A week after treatment with seaweed extract the CO2 uptake is measured again. These results are then compared with the results before treatment.

`Paired - two measures are taken for each study subject (plant)`

Researchers put 40 plants each in a separate greenhouse on two different tomato farms, and the CO2 uptake is measured for every plant. In both of the greenhouses, seaweed extract was added for half of the plants. After one week, the CO2 uptake is measured again for every plant, and the difference before and after is calculated. These differences are then compared between plants with and those without added extract.

`Paired - two measures are taken for each study subject (plant)`

Researchers split 40 plants in two groups. One group is treated with a seaweed extract A, the other group with another formula, seaweed extract B. After a week CO2 uptake is measure in each plant, and uptake is compared between both groups.

`Unpaired - only one observation is taken for each plant`
